        [Crossref], [PubMed], Google Scholar
        There is no corresponding record for this reference.
        (c) Zhuang, W.; Yuan, D.; Liu, D.; Zhong, C.; Li, J.-R.; Zhou, H.-C. Chem. Mater. 2012, 24, 18
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        4c
        Robust Metal-Organic Framework with An Octatopic Ligand for Gas Adsorption and Separation: Combined Characterization by Experiments and Molecular Simulation
        Zhuang, Wenjuan; Yuan, Daqiang; Liu, Dahuan; Zhong, Chongli; Li, Jian-Rong; Zhou, Hong-Cai
        Chemistry of Materials (2012), 24 (1), 18-25CODEN: CMATEX; ISSN:0897-4756. (American Chemical Society)
        A newly designed octatopic carboxylate ligand, tetrakis[(3,5-dicarboxyphenyl)oxamethyl]methane (TDM8-) was used to connect a dicopper paddlewheel building unit affording a metal-org. framework (MOF), Cu4(H2O)4(TDM)·xS (PCN-26·xS, S represents noncoordinated solvent mols., PCN = porous coordination network) with novel structure, high gas uptake, and interesting gas adsorption selectivity. PCN-26 contains two different types of cages, octahedral and cuboctahedral, to form a polyhedron-stacked three-dimensional framework with open channels in three orthogonal directions. Gas adsorption studies of N2, Ar, and H2 on an activated PCN-26 at 77 K, 1 bar, reveals a Langmuir surface area of 2545 m2/g, a Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area of 1854 m2/g, a total pore vol. of 0.84 cm3/g, and a H2 uptake capacity of 2.57%. Addnl., PCN-26 exhibits a CO2/N2 selectivity of 49:1 and CO2/CH4 selectivity of 8.4:1 at 273 K. To study properties of gas adsorption and the adsorption sites for CO2 in activated PCN-26, theor. simulations of the adsorption isotherms of CO2, CH4, and N2 at different temps. were carried out. Exptl. results corroborate very well with those of mol. simulations.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3MXhs1SmurnP&md5=36d3a3fd506da12d6a63b36613284d4f
      5. 5
        (a) Vaidhyanathan, R.; Iremonger, S. S.; Shimizu, G. K. H.; Boyd, P. G.; Alavi, S.; Woo, T. K. Science 2010, 330, 650
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        5a
        Direct Observation and Quantification of CO2 Binding Within an Amine-Functionalized Nanoporous Solid
        Vaidhyanathan, Ramanathan; Iremonger, Simon S.; Shimizu, George K. H.; Boyd, Peter G.; Alavi, Saman; Woo, Tom K.
        Science (Washington, DC, United States) (2010), 330 (6004), 650-653CODEN: SCIEAS; ISSN:0036-8075. (American Association for the Advancement of Science)
        Understanding the mol. details of CO2-sorbent interactions is crit. for the design of better carbon-capture systems. Here the authors report crystallog. resoln. of CO2 mols. and their binding domains in a metal-org. framework functionalized with amine groups. Accompanying computational studies that modeled the gas sorption isotherms, high heat of adsorption, and CO2 lattice positions showed high agreement on all three fronts. The modeling apportioned specific binding interactions for each CO2 mol., including substantial cooperative binding effects among the guest mols. The validation of the capacity of such simulations to accurately model mol.-scale binding bodes well for the theory-aided development of amine-based CO2 sorbents. The anal. shows that the combination of appropriate pore size, strongly interacting amine functional groups, and the cooperative binding of CO2 guest mols. is responsible for the low-pressure binding and large uptake of CO2 in this sorbent material.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3cXhtlaqt7nP&md5=62d8612e2927fcca9d6903619e95b042
        (b) Zhao, Y.; Wu, H.; Emge, T. J.; Gong, Q.; Nijem, N.; Chabal, Y. J.; Kong, L.; Langreth, D. C.; Liu, H.; Zeng, H.; Li, J. Chem.—Eur. J. 2011, 17, 5101
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        5b
        Enhancing Gas Adsorption and Separation Capacity through Ligand Functionalization of Microporous Metal-Organic Framework Structures
        Zhao, Yonggang; Wu, Haohan; Emge, Thomas J.; Gong, Qihan; Nijem, Nour; Chabal, Yves J.; Kong, Lingzhu; Langreth, David C.; Liu, Hui; Zeng, Heping; Li, Jing
        Chemistry - A European Journal (2011), 17 (18), 5101-5109, S5101/1-S5101/16CODEN: CEUJED; ISSN:0947-6539. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        Hydroxyl- and amino- functionalized [Zn(BDC)(TED)0.5].2DMF·0.2H2O leads to two new structures, [Zn(BDC-OH)(TED)0.5].1.5DMF.0.3H2O and [Zn(BDC-NH2)(TED)0.5].xDMF.yH2O (BDC = terephthalic acid, TED = triethylenediamine, BDC-OH = 2-hydroxylterephthalic acid, BDC-NH2 = 2-aminoterephthalic acid). Single-crystal x-ray diffraction and powder X-ray diffraction studies confirmed that the structures of both functionalized compds. are very similar to that of their parent structure. [Zn(BDC)(TED)0.5]·2DMF·0.2H2O can be considered a 3-dimensional porous structure with three interlacing 1-dimensional channels, whereas both [Zn(BDC-OH)(TED)0.5]·1.5DMF·0.3H2O and [Zn(BDC-NH2)(TED)0.5]·xDMF·yH2O contain only 1-dimensional open channels as a result of functionalization of the BDC ligand by the OH and NH2 groups. A notable decrease in surface area and pore size is thus obsd. in both compds. Consequently, [Zn(BDC)(TED)0.5]·2DMF·0.2H2O takes up the highest amt. of H2 at low temps. However, both [Zn(BDC-OH)(TED)0.5]·1.5DMF·0.3H2O and [Zn(BDC-NH2)(TED)0.5]·xDMF·yH2O show significant enhancement in CO2 uptake at room temp., suggesting that the strong interactions between CO2 and the functionalized ligands, indicating that surface chem., rather than porosity, plays a more important role in CO2 adsorption. A comparison of single-component CO2, CH4, CO, N2, and O2 adsorption isotherms demonstrates that the adsorption selectivity of CO2 over other small gases is considerably enhanced through functionalization of the frameworks. IR absorption spectroscopic measurements and theor. calcns. are also carried out to assess the effect of functional groups on CO2 and H2 adsorption potentials.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3MXkvVSmsr8%253D&md5=d1142d0645d8ca681e19630c822f45ad
        (c) Colombo, V.; Montoro, C.; Maspero, A.; Palmisano, G.; Masciocchi, N.; Galli, S.; Barea, E.; Navarro, J. A. R. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2012, 134, 12830
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        5c
        Tuning the Adsorption Properties of Isoreticular Pyrazolate-Based Metal-Organic Frameworks through Ligand Modification
        Colombo, Valentina; Montoro, Carmen; Maspero, Angelo; Palmisano, Giovanni; Masciocchi, Norberto; Galli, Simona; Barea, Elisa; Navarro, Jorge A. R.
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2012), 134 (30), 12830-12843CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        Two isoreticular series of pyrazolate-based 3-dimensional open metal-org. frameworks, MBDP_X, adopting the NiBDP and ZnBDP structure types [H2BDP = 1,4-bis(1H-pyrazol-4-yl)benzene], were synthesized with the new tagged org. linkers H2BDP_X (X = -NO2, -NH2, -OH). All of the MBDP_X materials were characterized through a combination of techniques. IR spectroscopy proved the effective presence of tags, while x-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) witnessed their isoreticular nature. Simultaneous TG/DSC analyses (STA) demonstrated their remarkable thermal stability, while variable-temp. XRPD expts. highlighted their high degree of flexibility related to guest-induced fit processes of the solvent mols. included in the channels. A structural isomer of the parent NiBDP was obtained with a sulfonate tagged ligand, H2BDP_SO3H. Structure soln. from powder diffraction data collected at three different temps. (room temp., 90, and 250°) allowed the detn. of its structure and the comprehension of its solvent-related flexible behavior. Finally, the potential application of the tagged MOFs in selective adsorption processes for gas sepn. and purifn. purposes was studied by conventional single component adsorption isotherms, as well as by advanced expts. of pulse gas chromatog. and breakthrough curve measurements. Noteworthy, functionalization does not improve the adsorption selectivity (partition coeffs.) for the resoln. of gas mixts. characterized by similar high quadrupole moments (e.g., CO2/C2H2); however, the resoln. of gas mixts. contg. mols. with highly differentiated polarities (i.e., N2/CO2 or CH4/CO2) is highly improved.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38Xps1GhsLo%253D&md5=bd22421dc325441f209a6d63ad2628b0
        (d) Henke, S.; Schmid, R.; Grunwaldt, J.-D.; Fischer, R. A. Chem.—Eur. J. 2010, 16, 14296

        5d
        Flexibility and Sorption Selectivity in Rigid Metal-Organic Frameworks: The Impact of Ether-Functionalised Linkers
        Henke, Sebastian; Schmid, Rochus; Grunwaldt, Jan-Dierk; Fischer, Roland A.
        Chemistry - A European Journal (2010), 16 (48), 14296-14306, S14296/1-S14296/33CODEN: CEUJED; ISSN:0947-6539. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        The functionalization of known rigid metal-org. frameworks (namely, [Zn4O(bdc)3]n, MOF-5, IRMOF-1 and [Zn2(bdc)2(dabco)]n; bdc = 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate, dabco = diazabicyclo[2.2.2]octane) with addnl. alkyl ether groups -O-(CH2)n-O-CH3 (n = 2-4) initiates unexpected structural flexibility, as well as high sorption selectivity towards CO2 over N2 and CH4 in the porous materials. These novel materials respond to the presence/absence of guest mols. with structural transformations. The chain length of the alkyl ether groups and the substitution pattern of the bdc-type linker have a major impact on structural flexibility and sorption selectivity. Remarkably, the authors' results show that a high cryst. order of the activated material is not a prerequisite to achieve significant porosity and high sorption selectivity.
        >> More from SciFinder ®

        (e) Vaidhyanathan, R.; Iremonger, S. S.; Dawson, K. W.; Shimizu, G. K. H. Chem. Commun. 2009, 5320

        5f
        Mesoporous Metal-Organic Frameworks with Size-tunable Cages: Selective CO2 Uptake, Encapsulation of Ln3+ Cations for Luminescence, and Column-Chromatographic Dye Separation
        Lan, Ya-Qian; Jiang, Hai-Long; Li, Shun-Li; Xu, Qiang
        Advanced Materials (Weinheim, Germany) (2011), 23 (43), 5015-5020CODEN: ADVMEW; ISSN:0935-9648. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        A series of mesoporous metal-org. frameworks MOFs with rare corundum topol. and tunable cage sizes has been rationally constructed by classical Zn4O clusters and pre-designed size-extendable tetratopic ligands. They all exhibit high and selective CO2/N2 uptake under ambient conditions and the CO2 uptake capability increases with larger cage sizes. Preliminary studies for lanthanide(III) cation encapsulation have indicated that the MOFs could potentially serve as barcoded luminescent materials. The MOF has been demonstrated to be a column-chromatog. filler for the sepn. of bulk dye mols. Extension of the current ligands for MOFs involving larger mesoporous cages with potential functional applications is currently underway.

        5g
        Gated Channels in a Honeycomb-like Zinc-Dicarboxylate-Bipyridine Framework with Flexible Alkyl Ether Side Chains
        Henke, Sebastian; Fischer, Roland A.
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2011), 133 (7), 2064-2067CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        Covalent functionalization of 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate (bdc) with methoxyethoxy groups induces conformational freedom in this mol. Applying these 2,5-disubstituted 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate (bdc) derivs. in metal-org. framework synthesis together with 4,4'-bipyridine as coligand yields novel honeycomb-like structures [Zn2L2P], (1; H2L = 2,5-bis(2-methoxyethoxy)-1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (H2BME-bdc); P = 4,4'-bipyridine (bipy)), {[Zn2(ME-bdc)2(bipy)]n(DMF)2.3(EtOH)0.4} (2; H2ME-bdc = 2-(2-methoxyethoxy)-1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid), [Zn2(BMP-bdc)2(bipy)]n (3; H2BMP-bdc = 2,5-bis(3-methoxypropoxy)-1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid) and [Zn2(BB-bdc)2(bipy)]n (4; H2BB-bdc = 2,5-bis(n-butoxy)-1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid). The cylindrical channels of these materials are populated with flexible groups, which act as mol. gates for guest mols. This allows highly selective sorption of CO2 over N2 and CH4.

        6a
        Fluorous Metal-Organic Frameworks for High-Density Gas Adsorption
        Yang, Chi; Wang, Xiaoping; Omary, Mohammad A.
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2007), 129 (50), 15454-15455CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        A fluorous metal-org. framework, FMOF-1, was obtained by reaction of Ag(I) with 3,5-bis(trifluoromethyl)-1,2,4-triazolate (Tz), giving rise to a neutral, H-free, extended 3-dimensional nanotubular porous framework consisting of tetranuclear clusters [Ag4Tz6]2- connected by three-coordinate Ag(I) centers. The fluoro-lined channels and cavities of the framework show hysteretic adsorption of H2 with a volumetric capacity of 41 kg/m3 at 77 K and 64 bar. Ag2[Ag4Tz6] also exhibits very high adsorptions for O2 and N2 with volumetric uptake of ∼550 and 400 kg/m3 at 77 K even at very low pressures (<10-2 bar).

        6b
        Crystallographic observation of dynamic gas adsorption sites and thermal expansion in a breathable fluorous metal-organic framework
        Yang, Chi; Wang, Xiaoping; Omary, Mohammad A.
        Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2009), 48 (14), 2500-2505CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        Cooling a single crystal of a microporous fluorous metal-org. framework under ambient atm. leads to very large breathing upon gas adsorption, during which multiple N2 mols. are filled into channels and cages. While the framework exhibits remarkable pos. thermal expansion under vacuum, a gigantic apparent neg. thermal expansion takes place when the crystal is exposed to N2 at ambient pressure.

        Functionalized coordination space in metal-organic frameworks
        Fischer, Roland A.; Woell, Christof
        Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2008), 47 (43), 8164-8168CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        A review. Discussion focuses on two significant advances in the development of metal-org. frameworks (MOFs): (1) perfluoro MOFs with an outstanding volumetric gas uptake and hysteretic sorption of dihydrogen; (2) the modular synthesis of functional MOFs involving a two-component framework, in which one component is an integral component of the framework and the other can be exchanged after formation of the matrix.

        Enhanced H2 adsorption enthalpy in the low-surface area, partially fluorinated coordination polymer Zn5(triazole)6(tetrafluoroterephthalate)2(H2O)2·4H2O
        Hulvey, Zeric; Falcao, Eduardo H. L.; Eckert, Juergen; Cheetham, Anthony K.
        Journal of Materials Chemistry (2009), 19 (25), 4307-4309CODEN: JMACEP; ISSN:0959-9428. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        A porous coordination polymer contg. zinc, 1,2,4-triazolate, and tetrafluoroterephthalate, Zn5(triazole)6(tetrafluoroterephthalate)2(H2O)2·4H2O, was prepd. and characterized by x-ray crystallog. It displays a high physisorptive hydrogen adsorption enthalpy of 8 kJ/mol, as a result of fluorine atoms exposed to the pore surface and the structure's small pore size.

        6e
        Hydrogen Storage in a Highly Interpenetrated and Partially Fluorinated Metal-Organic Framework
        Hulvey, Zeric; Sava, Dorina A.; Eckert, Juergen; Cheetham, Anthony K.
        Inorganic Chemistry (Washington, DC, United States) (2011), 50 (2), 403-405CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
        A partially fluorinated metal-org. framework, Zn(bpe)(tftpa)·cyclohexanone [bpe = 1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethane; tftpa = tetrafluoro terephthalate], was synthesized and its H2 storage properties are reported. The structure is highly interpenetrated yet contains templating cyclohexanone mols., which can be removed to give a porous material with F atoms exposed to the pore surface. The material adsorbs 1.04% H2 at 77 K and 1 atm with an adsorption enthalpy (Qst) of 6.2 kJ/mol, which represents a slight enhancement in the binding strength due to the presence of F atoms over comparable metal-org. frameworks, which bind through purely physisorptive methods.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3cXhsFOqtrbN&md5=b4f8b5fa38724e791f3dba6fb5409fc7
        (f) Chun, H.; Dybtsev, D. N.; Kim, H.; Kim, K. Chem.—Eur. J. 2005, 11, 3521
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        6f
        Synthesis, X-ray crystal structures, and gas sorption properties of pillared square grid nets based on paddle-wheel motifs: Implications for hydrogen storage in porous materials
        Chun, Hyungphil; Dybtsev, Danil N.; Kim, Hyunuk; Kim, Kimoon
        Chemistry - A European Journal (2005), 11 (12), 3521-3529CODEN: CEUJED; ISSN:0947-6539. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        A systematic modulation of org. ligands connecting dinuclear paddle-wheel motifs leads to isomorphous metal-org. porous materials that have a three-dimensional connectivity and interconnected pores. Arom. dicarboxylates such as 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate (1,4-bdc), tetramethylterephthalate (tmbdc), 1,4-naphthalenedicarboxylate (1,4-ndc), tetrafluoroterephthalate (tfbdc), or 2,6-naphthalenedicarboxylate (2,6-ndc) are linear linkers that form two-dimensional layers, and diamine ligands, 4-diazabicyclo[2.2.2]octane (dabco) or 4,4'-dipyridyl (bpy), coordinate at both sides of Zn2 paddle-wheel units to bridge the layers vertically. The resulting open frameworks [Zn2(1,4-bdc)2(dabco)] (1), [Zn2(1,4-bdc)(tmbdc)(dabco)] (2), [Zn2(tmbdc)2(dabco)] (3), [Zn2(1,4-ndc)2(dabco)] (4), [Zn2(tfbdc)2(dabco)] (5), and [Zn2(tmbdc)2(bpy)] (8) possess varying size of pores and free apertures originating from the side groups of the 1,4-bdc derivs. [Zn2(1,4-bdc)2(bpy)] (6) and [Zn2(2,6-ndc)2(bpy)] (7) have two- and 3-fold interpenetrating structures, resp. The noninterpenetrating frameworks (1-5 and 8) possess surface areas at 1450-2090 m2g-1 and H sorption capacities of 1.7-2.1% at 78 K and 1 atm. A detailed anal. of the sorption data in conjunction with structural similarities and differences concludes that porous materials with straight channels and large openings do not perform better than those with wavy channels and small openings in terms of H storage through physisorption.
        >> More from SciFinder ®

        (g) Fernandez, C. A.; Thallapally, P. K.; Motkuri, R. K.; Nune, S. K.; Sumrak, J. C.; Tian, J.; Liu, J. Cryst. Growth Des. 2010, 10, 1037
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        6g
        Gas-Induced Expansion and Contraction of a Fluorinated Metal-Organic Framework

        Crystal Growth & Design (2010), 10 (3), 1037-1039CODEN: CGDEFU; ISSN:1528-7483. (American Chemical Society)
        Synthesis and gas sorption properties of a novel fluorinated metal-org. framework of zinc(II) using com. available 2,2'-bis(4-carboxyphenyl)hexafluoropropane is reported with high selectivity toward CO2, H2S, and SO2 as well as breathing motion upon solvent removal and gas inclusion.

        6h
        Unusual room temperature CO2 uptake in a fluoro-functionalized MOF: insight from Raman spectroscopy and theoretical studies
        Kanoo, Prakash; Reddy, Sandeep Kumar; Kumari, Gayatri; Haldar, Ritesh; Narayana, Chandrabhas; Balasubramanian, Sundaram; Maji, Tapas Kumar
        Chemical Communications (Cambridge, United Kingdom) (2012), 48 (68), 8487-8489CODEN: CHCOFS; ISSN:1359-7345. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        The authors herein report an unusual CO2 adsorption behavior in a fluoro-functionalized MOF {[Zn(SiF6)(pyz)2]·2MeOH}n (1) with a 1-dimensional channel system, which is made up of pyrazine and SiF62- moieties. Surprisingly, desolvated 1 (1') adsorbs higher amts. of CO2 at 298 K than at 195 K, which is in contrast to the usual trend. Combined Raman spectroscopic and theor. studies reveal that slanted pyrazine rings in 1' with an angle of 17.2° with respect to the (200) Zn(II)-Si plane at low temp. block the channel windows and thus reduce the uptake amt.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38XhtFaju7rO&md5=38ccd3194f3eb510fcde31bb05f304b2
        (i) Yang, W.; Lin, X.; Blake, A. J.; Wilson, C.; Hubberstey, P.; Champness, N. R.; Schroder, M. Inorg. Chem. 2009, 48, 11067
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        6i
        Self-Assembly of Metal-Organic Coordination Polymers Constructed from a Bent Dicarboxylate Ligand: Diversity of Coordination Modes, Structures, and Gas Adsorption
        Yang, Wenbin; Lin, Xiang; Blake, Alexander J.; Wilson, Claire; Hubberstey, Peter; Champness, Neil R.; Schroder, Martin
        Inorganic Chemistry (2009), 48 (23), 11067-11078CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
        The authors synthesized five new metal-org. coordination polymers incorporating the bent ligand H2hfipbb [4,4'-(hexafluoroisopropylidene)bis(benzoic acid)] with different transition metal ions and co-ligands via solvothermal reactions to give [Zn2(hfipbb)2(py)2]·DMF (1), [Zn2(hfipbb)2(4,4'-bipy)(H2O)] (2), [Zn2(hfipbb)2(bpdab)]·2DMF (3), [Cd2(hfipbb)2(DMF)2]·2DMF (4), and [Co(hfipbb)(dpp)]·MeOH (5) (py = pyridine, 4,4'-bipy = 4,4'-bipyridine, bpdab = 1,4-bis(4-pyridyl)-2,3-diaza-1,3-butadiene, dpp = 1,3-di(4-pyridyl)propane). Compd. 1 displays a 2-fold 2D→2D parallel interpenetrated layer network with 1-dimensional (1D) helical channels, while 3 exhibits a three-dimensional pillared helical-layer open framework of α-Po topol. based upon binuclear paddle-wheel units. In compds. 2 and 5, binuclear motifs with double carboxylate bridges are linked by hfipbb2- ligands into a 1-dimensional ribbon, which are further assembled into two-dimensional non-interpenetrated (4,4) layers via bipyridyl co-ligands. However, the different bridging modes of hfipbb2- ligands and the different disposition of the coordinated co-ligands around metal ions result in subtle differences in the final architecture. Thus, 2 is based on a binuclear cluster node, double-stranded hfipbb2- linkers, and single-stranded 4,4'-bipy linkers, while 5 is based on a binuclear cluster node and hfipbb2- and dpp linkers which are both double-stranded. Among these compds., the Cd(II) complex 4 is possibly the most interesting because it represents a rare example in which metal centers are linked by carboxylate groups into infinite chains further joined together by hfipbb2- spacers to form a 2-dimensional network with tubular helical channels. All these coordination polymers exhibit low solvent-accessible vols. Both 3 and 4 retain structural integrity and permanent microporosity upon evacuation of guest mols., with H uptakes of 0.57 and 0.78%, resp., at 20 bar and 77 K.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXhtlCkurfN&md5=dca16e4f836c1063826159080f6f764b
        (j) Pachfule, P.; Das, R.; Poddar, P.; Banerjee, R. Inorg. Chem. 2011, 50, 3855
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        6j
        Structural, Magnetic, and Gas Adsorption Study of a Series of Partially Fluorinated Metal-Organic Frameworks (HF-MOFs)
        Pachfule, Pradip; Das, Raja; Poddar, Pankaj; Banerjee, Rahul
        Inorganic Chemistry (2011), 50 (9), 3855-3865CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
        Four new partially fluorinated metal org. frameworks (HF-MOFs) were synthesized under different solvothermal conditions (H2O or DMF) from transition metal cations [Co2+ and Mn2+], 3-methylpyridine (3-mepy) and 4,4'-(hexafluoroisopropylidene)bis(benzoic acid) (C17H10F6O4, H2hfbba), to det. the influence of reaction conditions on the formation of MOFs. This family of materials displays a striking degree of structural similarity depending on the solvent of synthesis. HF-MOFs synthesized from H2O [Co-HFMOF-W, Co(hfbba)(3-mepy)(H2O) and Mn-HFMOF-W, Mn(hfbba)(3-mepy)(H2O)] contain three-dimensional connectivity whereas HF-MOFs synthesized from DMF Co-HFMOF-D, [Co2(hfbba)2(3-mepy)2]·(DMF)3 and Mn-HFMOF-D, [Mn2(hfbba)2(3-mepy)]·(H2O) are two-dimensional in nature. Co-HFMOF-W and Mn-HFMOF-W are iso-structural polymeric materials. TGA performed on as-synthesized HF-MOFs revealed that these compds. have high thermal stability (∼ 350°). The continuous decrease of the χT product with decreasing T for Co-HFMOF-D and Co-HFMOF-W resp. indicates antiferromagnetic exchange interaction between two Co2+ (S = 3/2) metal centers within a cluster.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3MXjvVeitLY%253D&md5=d88b2d34b5029721e7c039f0506daef0

        (b) Nyffeler, P. T.; Durn, S. G.; Burkart, M. D.; Vincent, S. P.; Wong, C.-H. Angew. Chem., Int. Ed. 2005, 44, 192
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar

        Selectfluor: Mechanistic insight and applications
        Nyffeler, Paul T.; Duron, Sergio Gonzalez; Burkart, Michael D.; Vincent, Stephane P.; Wong, Chi-Huey
        Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2005), 44 (2), 192-212CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        A review discusses the prepn. and reactions of Selectfluor [1-(chloromethyl)-4-fluorodiazoniabicyclo[2.2.2]octane bis(tetrafluoroborate)] (I). The synthesis and properties of I, its use in electrophilic fluorination, in enantioselective reactions, and in other reactions, the mechanism of fluorination reactions mediated by I, and applications of fluorinated compds. are discussed.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2MXjtFCktQ%253D%253D&md5=05a4961f5c86d0f6607f4ca602a604b9
        (c) Horvath, I. T.; Rabai, J. Science 1994, 266, 72
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        7c
        Facile catalyst separation without water: fluorous biphase hydroformylation of olefins
        Horvath, Istvan T.; Rabai, Jozsef
        Science (Washington, DC, United States) (1994), 266 (5182), 72-5CODEN: SCIEAS; ISSN:0036-8075.
        A novel concept for performing stoichiometric and catalytic chem. transformations has been developed that is based on the limited miscibility of partially or fully fluorinated compds. with nonfluorinated compds. A fluorous biphase system (FBS) consists of a fluorous phase contg. a dissolved reagent or catalyst and another phase, which could be any common org. or nonorg. solvent with limited or no soly. in the fluorous phase. The fluorous phase is defined as the fluorocarbon (mostly perfluorinated alkanes, ethers, and tertiary amines)-rich phase of a biphase system. An FBS compatible reagent or catalyst contains enough fluorous moieties that it will be sol. only or preferentially in the fluorous phase. The most effective fluorous moieties are linear or branched perfluoroalkyl chains with high carbon no.; they may also contain heteroatoms. The chem. transformation may occur either in the fluorous phase or at the interface of the two phases. The application of FBS has been demonstrated for the extn. of rhodium from toluene and for the hydroformylation of olefins. The ability to sep. a catalyst or a reagent from the products completely under mild conditions could lead to industrial application of homogeneous catalysts or reagents and to the development of more environmentally benign processes.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK2MXhtF2ns7o%253D&md5=674c1b0b85dfe36a5942b2fcc3acfec5
        (d) Pagliaro, M.; Ciriminna, R. J. Mater. Chem. 2005, 15, 4981
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        7d
        New fluorinated functional materials
        Pagliaro, Mario; Ciriminna, Rosaria
        Journal of Materials Chemistry (2005), 15 (47), 4981-4991CODEN: JMACEP; ISSN:0959-9428. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        A review. Whether in catalysis, biol. or the protection of the environment, fluorinated functional materials are emerging as important chem. tools to achieve improved performance and higher stability under a variety of conditions. Providing a distinct increase in mol. hydrophobicity, fluorination allows easy tuning of a material's hydrophilic-lipophilic balance (HLB), in particular with sol-gel materials obtained by polycondensation of fluorinated precursors. Reporting on recent remarkable achievements, this review attempts to show the large unexplored potential of these materials.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2MXht1GjtrjE&md5=f02b3f727c3e8330451dc2a1455fd9ef
        (e) Reichenbächer, K.; Süss, H. I.; Hulliger, J. Chem. Soc. Rev. 2005, 34, 22
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        7e
        Fluorine in crystal engineering--"the little atom that could"
        Reichenbacher Katharina; Suss Heike I; Hulliger Jurg
        Chemical Society reviews (2005), 34 (1), 22-30 ISSN:0306-0012.
        In the last decade interactions of fluorine substituents in a variety of organic compounds have gained interest in life science and solid state materials. This review provides knowledge on fluorine interactions classified into phenyl-perfluorophenyl-, C-FH, FF and C-FpiF interactions. Except for phenyl-perfluorophenyl stacking featuring a stabilising energy of about 30 kJ.mol(-1), interactions involving fluorine are generally weak. Although, there is still no concise understanding of fluorine interactions, there are numerous examples showing the influence of weak synthons on chemical, physical and biological properties.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A280%3ADC%252BD2M%252Fhs1equw%253D%253D&md5=25443f507fedcd54f4c5d876778494ff

        Eddaoudi, M.; Kim, J.; Rosi, N.; Vodak, D.; Wachter, J.; O’Keeffe, M.; Yaghi, O. M. Science 2002, 295, 469
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        8
        Systematic design of pore size and functionality in isoreticular MOFs and their application in methane storage
        Eddaoudi, Mohamed; Kim, Jaheon; Rosi, Nathaniel; Vodak, David; Wachter, Joseph; O'Keeffe, Michael; Yaghi, Omar M.
        Science (Washington, DC, United States) (2002), 295 (5554), 469-472CODEN: SCIEAS; ISSN:0036-8075. (American Association for the Advancement of Science)
        A strategy based on reticulating metal ions and org. carboxylate links into extended networks has been advanced to a point that allowed the design of porous structures in which pore size and functionality could be varied systematically. Metal-org. framework (MOF-5), a prototype of a new class of porous materials and one that is constructed from octahedral Zn-O-C clusters and benzene links, was used to demonstrate that its three-dimensional porous system can be functionalized with the org. groups -Br, -NH2, -OC3H7, -OC5H11, -C2H4, and -C4H4 and that its pore size can be expanded with the long mol. struts biphenyl, tetrahydropyrene, pyrene, and terphenyl. We synthesized an isoreticular series (one that has the same framework topol.) of 16 highly cryst. materials whose open space represented up to 91.1% of the crystal vol., as well as homogeneous periodic pores that can be incrementally varied from 3.8 to 28.8 Å. One member of this series exhibited a high capacity for methane storage (240 cm3 at std. temp.), and others the lowest densities (0.41 to 0.21 g/cm3) for a cryst. material at room temp.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1cXhtlyrtLjP&md5=d218d4040887f5fb390a733ee156d27b

        (a) Zhang, J. J.; Wojtas, L.; Larsen, R. W.; Eddaoudi, M.; Zaworotko, M. J. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2009, 131, 17040
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        9a
        Temperature and Concentration Control over Interpenetration in a Metal-Organic Material
        Zhang, JianJun; Wojtas, Lukasz; Larsen, Randy W.; Eddaoudi, Mohamed; Zaworotko, Michael J.
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2009), 131 (47), 17040-17041CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        A pillared framework formed from 4,4'-bipyridine (bipy) and sheets of dinuclear Cd2 nodes and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (bdc) linkers can be solvothermally prepd. in both interpenetrated, [Cd(bipy)(bdc)], and noninterpenetrated, [Cd(bipy)(bdc)]·3DMF·H2O, forms by simply varying the temp. or concn. of the reaction. Higher temps. and concns. favor interpenetration over the corresponding noninterpenetrating structure, an observation that could have broad implications for controlling the synthesis of metal-org. materials (MOFs).
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXhtlKrsb%252FF&md5=1c3a2b9127fa400791f92a30d970a6bd
        (b) Song, F.; Wang, C.; Falkowski, J. M.; Ma, L.; Lin, W. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2010, 132, 15390
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        9b
        Isoreticular Chiral Metal-Organic Frameworks for Asymmetric Alkene Epoxidation: Tuning Catalytic Activity by Controlling Framework Catenation and Varying Open Channel Sizes
        Song, Fei-Jie; Wang, Cheng; Falkowski, Joseph M.; Ma, Li-Qing; Lin, Wen-Bin
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2010), 132 (43), 15390-15398CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        A family of isoreticular chiral metal-org. frameworks (CMOFs) of the primitive cubic network topol. was constructed from [Zn4(μ4-O)(O2CR)3] secondary building units and systematically elongated dicarboxylate struts that are derived from chiral Mn-Salen catalytic subunits (R). CMOFs 1-5 were synthesized by directly incorporating three different chiral Mn-Salen struts into the frameworks under solvothermal conditions, and they were characterized by a variety of methods, including single-crystal x-ray diffraction, PXRD, TGA, and 1H NMR. Although the CMOFs 1 vs. 2 and CMOFs 3 vs. 4 pairs were constructed from the same building blocks, they exhibit two-fold interpenetrated or noninterpenetrated structures, resp., depending on the steric sizes of the solvents that were used to grow the MOF crystals. For CMOF-5, only a 3-fold interpenetrated structure was obtained due to the extreme length of the Mn-Salen-derived dicarboxylate strut. The open channel and pore sizes of the CMOF series vary systematically, owing to the tunable dicarboxylate struts and controllable interpenetration patterns. CMOFs 1-5 are highly effective catalysts for asym. epoxidn. of a variety of unfunctionalized olefins with up to 92% ee. The rates of epoxidn. reactions strongly depend on the CMOF open channel sizes, and the catalytic activities of CMOFs 2 and 4 approach that of a homogeneous control catalyst. Probably although the diffusion of bulky alkene and oxidant reagents can be a rate-limiting factor in MOF-catalyzed asym. reactions, the catalytic activity of the CMOFs with large open channels (such as CMOFs 2 and 4 in the present study) is limited by the intrinsic reactivity of the catalytic mol. building blocks. The CMOF catalysts are recyclable and reusable and retain their framework structures after epoxidn. reactions. This work highlights the potential of generating highly effective heterogeneous asym. catalysts via direct incorporation of well-defined homogeneous catalysts into framework structures of MOFs.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3cXht1KrsL7O&md5=2a5780586e3351a29f9047cba59aa06a
      10. 10
        Chen, J.-C.; Hing, C.-J.; Liu, Y.-C. Synth. Met. 2010, 160, 1953
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        10
        Synthesis, optical and electrochemical properties of novel hole-blocking poly(biphenylene-1,3,4-oxadiazole) containing electron-withdrawing trifluoromethyl groups
        Chen, Jyh-Chien; Chiang, Chi-Jui; Liu, Yen-Chun
        Synthetic Metals (2010), 160 (17-18), 1953-1961CODEN: SYMEDZ; ISSN:0379-6779. (Elsevier B.V.)
        New poly(biphenylene-1,3,4-oxadiazole) P1 and poly(biphenylene hydrazide) P2 contg. electron-withdrawing trifluoromethyl group at the 2 and 2' positions of biphenyl moiety were synthesized. The biphenyl is forced to adapt a non-coplanar conformation due to the bulky trifluoromethyl group. High quality polymer P1 thin film can be easily obtained by thermal cyclodehydration from its sol. polyhydrazide precursor P2. The polymer P1 exhibited good thermal stability with glass transition temp. of 234 °C and 5% decompn. temp. of 469 °C. The optical and electrochem. properties were investigated by UV-vis spectroscopy, photoluminescence spectroscopy and cyclic voltammetry. For polymer P1 film, two absorption peaks at 370 and 414 nm were obsd. It also exhibited a photoluminescent peak at 555 nm when excited by 414 nm light. The cyclic voltammetric studies revealed that polymer P1 had extremely low HOMO (-6.85 eV) and LUMO (-3.71 eV) energy levels due to the presence of strong electron-withdrawing trifluoromethyl group. It also exhibited a large energy gap (3.14 eV) which is an indication of short conjugation length resulted from non-coplanar biphenyl structure. Its HOMO energy was even lower than that of widely used hole-blocking material, 2-(4-biphenyl)-5-(4-tert-butylphenyl)-1,3,4-oxadiazole PBD (-6.30 eV). The low LUMO energy of polymer P1 could allow the easier electron injection from air-stable cathode such as aluminum. The good electron transfer ability was also shown by measuring the c.d. of electron-only devices with the structures of Al/P1 (150 nm)/Alq3 (50 nm)/Al and Al/Alq3 (200 nm)/Al. Combined with high thermal stability and amorphous morphol., polymer P1 would be a promising candidate as the hole-blocking material for org. light-emitting diodes.
        >> More from SciFinder ®

        High pressure methane adsorption in the metal-organic frameworks Cu3(btc)2, Zn2(bdc)2dabco, and Cr3F(H2O)2O(bdc)3
        Senkovska, Irena; Kaskel, Stefan
        Microporous and Mesoporous Materials (2008), 112 (1-3), 108-115CODEN: MIMMFJ; ISSN:1387-1811. (Elsevier)
        Three porous coordination polymers Cu3(btc)2 (HKUST-1) (btc = benzene-1,3,5-tricarboxylate) (1), Zn2(bdc)2dabco (2) (bdc = benzene-1,4-dicarboxylate, dabco = 1,4-diazabicyclo[2.2.2]octane), and Cr3F(H2O)2O(bdc)3 (MIL-101) (3) were evaluated as methane storage materials. The compds. were synthesized using solvothermal method and identified as pure phases using powder x-ray diffraction. Nitrogen physisorption at 77 K revealed a high specific micropore vol. ranging from 0.75 to 1.303 cm3 g-1. Methane adsorption isotherms were measured using gravimetric method at 303 K up to 200 bar. A volumetric miniature tank system was used to measure the effective volumetric storage capacity taking the packing d. into account. Among the three materials, Cu3(btc)2 shows the highest excess adsorption at 303 K (15.7%) and effective volumetric storage capacity of 228 m3 m-3 (150 bar), whereas for Zn2(bdc)2dabco and MIL-101 the max. excess adsorption is lower (14.3 and 14.2%, resp.). For MIL-101, the max. in the excess adsorption is obsd. at higher pressure (125 bar) as compared to Cu3(btc)2 and Zn2(bdc)2dabco (75 bar).

        (a) Sharma, M. K.; Bharadwaj, P. K. Inorg. Chem. 2011, 50, 1889
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        18a
        A Dynamic Open Framework Exhibiting Guest- and/or Temperature-Induced Bicycle-Pedal Motion in Single-Crystal to Single-Crystal Transformation
        Sharma, Manish K.; Bharadwaj, Parimal K.
        Inorganic Chemistry (2011), 50 (5), 1889-1897CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
        A ligand bis(4-imidazol-1-yl-phenyl)diazene (azim) incorporating an azo moiety at the center and two imidazole groups at the terminals forms two coordination polymers {[Co(azim)2(DMF)2](ClO4)2·2DMF}n (1) and {[Cd(azim)2(DMF)2](ClO4)2·2DMF}n (2) at room temp. Both 1 and 2 are isostructural with rhombic two-dimensional sheets stacking in ABAB... fashion resulting in large voids that contain DMF and ClO4 as guests. In 1, the azo groups and Ph rings are disordered over two positions and as in usual cases, the pedal motion cannot be discerned. Upon heating, 1 turns amorphous. In the case of 2, however, heat treatment does not lead to loss of crystallinity. Thus, when a crystal of 2 (mother crystal) is heated slowly, it causes substantial movement or escape of both metal-bound and lattice DMF besides movement of ClO4 anions to give daughter crystals 2a, 2b, and 2c without losing crystallinity (single-crystal to single-crystal (SC-SC) transformation). Most interestingly, the x-ray structures of 2 and its daughter products reveal stepwise reversible bicycle-pedal or crankshaft motion of the azo group. When a crystal of 2c is kept in DMF for 10 h, crystal 2' is formed whose structure is similar to that of 2 with slight changes in the bond distances and angles. Also, crystals of 2 are converted to 3 and 4 upon being kept in acetone or DEF (DEF = N,N'-diethylformamide), resp., for 10 h at ambient temp. in SC-SC transformation. In 3, each lattice DMF mol. is replaced by an acetone mol., leaving the two coordinated DMF mols. intact. However, in 4, all lattice and coordinated DMF mols. are replaced by equal no. of DEF mols. Both in 3 and 4, the azo moieties show bicycle-pedal motion. Thus, bicycle-pedal motion that normally cannot be obsd. is shown here to be triggered by heat as well as guest mols. in SC-SC fashion.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3MXoslyntQ%253D%253D&md5=c7d904706a3f344b9d59776a0d623289
        (b) Aijaz, A.; Lama, P.; Bharadwaj, P. K. Inorg. Chem. 2010, 49, 5883
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        18b
        Two-Dimensional Coordination Polymer with a Non-interpenetrated (4,4) Net Showing Anion Exchange and Structural Transformation in Single-Crystal-to-Single-Crystal Fashion
        Aijaz, Arshad; Lama, Prem; Bharadwaj, Parimal K.
        Inorganic Chemistry (Washington, DC, United States) (2010), 49 (13), 5883-5889CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
        A new non-interpenetrated two-dimensional (2D) rectangular-grid coordination polymer, {[Co(L)2(H2O)2](BF4)2·4DMF}n (1), was synthesized using a new rod-like ligand, 3,5-bis(4-imidazol-1-ylphenyl)-[1,2,4]triazol-4-ylamine (L). Weakly H-bonded BF4- anions present within the voids can be exchanged by ClO4- and NO3- anions to generate {[Co(L)2(H2O)2](ClO4)2·2DMF·2H2O}n (2) and {[Co(L)2(H2O)2](NO3)2·2DMF·2H2O}n (3) in single-crystal-to-single-crystal (SC-SC) manner. In the case of exchange by Cl- ion, the crystallinity is not maintained as proven by IR spectroscopy, PXRD, and elemental anal. 3 Shows an interesting structural transformation (2-dimensional → 1D) with bond rupture/formation giving a new coordination polymer, {[Co(L)2(H2O)2](NO3)2·2DMF·H2O}n, (5), again in SC-SC fashion.

        18c
        A Porous Coordination Polymer Exhibiting Reversible Single-Crystal to Single-Crystal Substitution Reactions at Mn(II) Centers by Nitrile Guest Molecules
        Das, Madhab C.; Bharadwaj, Parimal K.
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2009), 131 (31), 10942-10949CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        The porous coordination polymer {[Mn(L)(H2O)](H2O)1.5(DMF)}n (1) contg. a H2O mol. coordinated at the apical position of each distorted octahedral Mn(II) center was synthesized using the solvothermal technique by reacting Mn(NO3)2·4H2O with a new flexible ligand I (LH2) having isophthalic fragment and pyridine donors at the two ends. The coordinated H2O mol. could be substituted by nitrile guest mols. such as MeCN, acrylonitrile, allylnitrile, and crotononitrile (affording compds. 2-5, resp.) without loss of crystallinity. Compd. 1 selectively captures cis-crotononitrile into its cavity from a mixt. of cis and trans isomers. Hence, the cis isomer can be sepd. from the trans isomer. In each case, 1.5 lattice H2O mols. and a DMF mol. are also simultaneously replaced by certain nos. of these guest mols. When these first-generation compds. 2-5 are dipped in DMF at room temp. with the lid of the vial open to the atm., the mother crystal 1 is regenerated in each case. Thus, all of these substitution reactions are completely reversible. Also, the first-generation compds. 2-5 can be interconverted among one another by dipping them in appropriate nitrile guests. All of these phenomena could be obsd. in single-crystal to single-crystal fashion.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXoslCnurY%253D&md5=9428ff98a7b281265bbe88d48cacc39e

        (a) Dinca, M.; Long, J. R. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2007, 129, 11172

        19a
        High-Enthalpy Hydrogen Adsorption in Cation-Exchanged Variants of the Microporous Metal-Organic Framework Mn3[(Mn4Cl)3(BTT)8(CH3OH)10]2
        Dinca, Mircea; Long, Jeffrey R.
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2007), 129 (36), 11172-11176CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        Exchange of the guest Mn2+ ions in Mn3[(Mn4Cl)3(BTT)8(MeOH)10]2 (1-Mn2+; BTT = 1,3,5-benzenetristetrazolate) with selected cations gave isostructural framework compds. 1-M (M = Li+, Cu+, Fe2+, Co2+, Ni2+, Cu2+, Zn2+). Similar to the parent compd., the new microporous materials are stable to desolvation and exhibit a high H2 storage capacity, ranging from 2.00 to 2.29% at 77 K and 900 torr. Measurements of the isosteric heat of adsorption at zero coverage reveal a difference of 2 kJ/mol between the weakest and strongest H2-binding materials, which is attributed to variations in the strength of interaction between H2 mols. and unsatd. metal centers within each framework. The Co2+-exchanged compd., 1-Co2+, exhibits an initial enthalpy of adsorption of 10.5 kJ/mol, the highest yet obsd. for a microporous metal-org. framework.

        19b
        Characterization of interfacial water in MOF-5 (Zn4(O)(BDC)3)--a combined spectroscopic and theoretical study
        Schrock K; Schroder F; Heyden M; Fischer R A; Havenith M
        Physical chemistry chemical physics : PCCP (2008), 10 (32), 4732-9 ISSN:1463-9076.
        In this article we report the detection and characterization of adsorbed interfacial water within the cages of the metal-organic framework MOF-5 (Zn(4)O(BDC)(3)) by terahertz time-domain spectroscopy (THz TDS) in the frequency range from 5 to 46 cm(-1). The experimental spectra suggest a coupling of the intermolecular motions of the water molecules adsorbed to the collective vibrations of the network at 4 wt% hydration. This finding is supported by the results of MD simulations. When increasing the water content to 8 wt% we observed a non reversible decomposition of MOF-5.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A280%3ADC%252BD1crgs1aitg%253D%253D&md5=ef42ec9d2b815bc477bda6641e06d568
        (c) Park, K. S.; Ni, Z.; Cote, A. P.; Choi, J. Y.; Huang, R.; Uribe-Romo, F. J.; Chae, H. K.; O’ Keeffe, M.; Yaghi, O. M. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 2006, 103, 10186
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        19c
        Exceptional chemical and thermal stability of zeolitic imidazolate frameworks
        Park, Kyo Sung; Ni, Zheng; Cote, Adrien P.; Choi, Jae Yong; Huang, Rudan; Uribe-Romo, Fernando J.; Chae, Hee K.; O'Keeffe, Michael; Yaghi, Omar M.
        Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America (2006), 103 (27), 10186-10191CODEN: PNASA6; ISSN:0027-8424. (National Academy of Sciences)
        Twelve zeolitic imidazolate frameworks (ZIFs; termed ZIF-1 to -12) were synthesized as crystals by copolymn. of either Zn(II) (ZIF-1 to -4, -6 to -8, and -10 to -11) or Co(II) (ZIF-9 and -12) with imidazolate-type links. The ZIF crystal structures are based on the nets of seven distinct aluminosilicate zeolites: tetrahedral Si(Al) and the bridging O are replaced with transition metal ion and imidazolate link, resp. One example of mixed-coordination imidazolate of Zn(II) and In(III) (ZIF-5) based on the garnet net is reported. Study of the gas adsorption and thermal and chem. stability of two prototypical members, ZIF-8 and -11, demonstrated their permanent porosity (Langmuir surface area = 1,810 m2/g), high thermal stability (up to 550°), and remarkable chem. resistance to boiling alk. H2O and org. solvents.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD28XntlKjtbo%253D&md5=c28cd5862d4765fe4e4937195f5bb4df
      20. 20
        (a) Decoste, J. B.; Peterson, G. W.; Smith, M. W.; Stone, C. A.; Willis, C. R. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2012, 134, 1486
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        20a
        Enhanced Stability of Cu-BTC MOF via Perfluorohexane Plasma-Enhanced Chemical Vapor Deposition
        Decoste, Jared B.; Peterson, Gregory W.; Smith, Martin W.; Stone, Corinne A.; Willis, Colin R.
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2012), 134 (3), 1486-1489CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        Metal org. frameworks (MOFs) are a leading class of porous materials for a wide variety of applications, but many of them are unstable toward water. Cu-BTC (1,3,5 benzenetricarboxylic acid, BTC) was treated with a plasma-enhanced CVD (PECVD) of perfluorohexane creating a hydrophobic form of Cu-BTC. The treated Cu-BTC could withstand high humidity and even submersion in water much better than unperturbed Cu-BTC. Through Monte Carlo simulations perfluorohexane sites itself in such a way within Cu-BTC as to prevent the formation of water clusters, hence preventing the decompn. of Cu-BTC by water. This PECVD of perfluorohexane could be exploited to widen the scope of practical applications of Cu-BTC and other MOFs.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38Xks1agtA%253D%253D&md5=70c788eb90c8a28d5e33e79ae84050af

        20b
        Methyl modified MOF-5: a water stable hydrogen storage material
        Yang, Jie; Grzech, Anna; Mulder, Fokko M.; Dingemans, Theo J.
        Chemical Communications (Cambridge, United Kingdom) (2011), 47 (18), 5244-5246CODEN: CHCOFS; ISSN:1359-7345. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        Water stable Me modified MOF-5s were synthesized via a solvothermal route. Methyl- and 2,5-dimethyl-modified MOF-5s show the same topol. and hydrogen uptake capability as that of MOF-5. The H2 uptake capacity of MOF-5, however, drops rapidly when exposed to the ambient air, whereas the H2 uptake capacities of the Me modified MOF-5s remain stable for 4 days.

        A structural paradigm for 3-periodic semiregular (46.69)-hxg net with high-symmetry hexagonal geometry, constructed from the linear [Cd2NaO6(H2O)6] SBUs and a flexible 6,6'-dithiodinicotinate linker
        Liu, Chun-Sen; Yang, Xiao-Gang; Hu, Min; Du, Miao; Fang, Shao-Ming
        Chemical Communications (Cambridge, United Kingdom) (2012), 48 (60), 7459-7461CODEN: CHCOFS; ISSN:1359-7345. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        Reaction of 6,6'-dithiodinicotinic acid (H2dtdn) with cadmium(II) perchlorate in presence of NaOH produces a 3-D metal-org. framework constructed from the linear trimetallic [Cd2NaO6(H2O)6] secondary building units and a long flexible 6,6'-dithiodinicotinate tecton is presented, which has a 6-connected (46.69)-hxg network with high-symmetry hexagonal geometries. Single crystal X-ray diffraction reveals the heterometallic trinuclear units [Cd2NaO6(H2O)6] act as the SBUs in this structure, where the Cd(II) and Na(I) ions have different coordination environments although both of them are six-coordinated. The Cd(II) atom, located at a site with crystallog.-imposed 3-fold symmetry, is surrounded by six oxygen donors from three different dtdn ligands and three aqua mols. The coordination sphere of Na(I) center is provided by the carboxylate oxygen atoms from six different dtdn ligands. Thermal stability and solid-state luminescence of the framework are reported.
        >> More from SciFinder ®

        24a
        Hydrogen storage in the giant-pore metal-organic frameworks MIL-100 and MIL-101
        Latroche, Michel; Suble, Suzy; Serre, Christian; Mellot-Draznieks, Caroline; Llewellyn, Philip L.; Lee, Jin-Ho; Chang, Jong-San; Jhung, Sung Hwa; Ferey, Gerard
        Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2006), 45 (48), 8227-8231CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        The metal-org. framework MIL-101 absorbs large amts. of H with a capacity of about 6.1 wt.% at liq.-N temps. - it also has the highest heat of adsorption so far (10 kJ/mol). However, MIL-101 has low hydrogen uptake at room temp. The small pores of MIL-101 play a major role in H absorption and the large empty space generated by the large cages leads to very large pores that are not as effective for H storage. In the architecture of this porous solid each intersection of the cages is occupied by a super-tetrahedron formed by trimers of Cr octahedra assembled with benzene-1,4-dicarboxylate ligands.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD28XhtlGnsLjP&md5=9da229e145247a04fba4f90a912d9170
        (b) Ma, S.; Eckert, J.; Forster, P. M.; Yoon, J. W.; Hwang, Y. K.; Chang, J.-S.; Collier, C. D.; Parise, J. B.; Zhou, H.-C. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2008, 130, 15896
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        24b
        Further Investigation of the Effect of Framework Catenation on Hydrogen Uptake in Metal-Organic Frameworks
        Ma, Shengqian; Eckert, Juergen; Forster, Paul M.; Yoon, Ji Woong; Hwang, Young Kyu; Chang, Jong-San; Collier, Christopher D.; Parise, John B.; Zhou, Hong-Cai
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2008), 130 (47), 15896-15902CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        Hydrogen-sorption studies were carried out for the catenation isomer pairs of PCN-6 and PCN-6' (both have the formula of Cu3(TATB)2, where TATB represents 4,4',4''-s-triazine-2,4,6-triyl-tribenzoate of C24H12N3O6). Inelastic neutron scattering (INS) studies reveal that the initial sites occupied by adsorbed H2 are the open Cu centers of the paddlewheel units with comparable interaction energies in the two isomers. At high H2 loadings, where the H2 mols. adsorb mainly on or around the org. linkers, the interaction is substantially stronger in catenated PCN-6 than in noncatenated PCN-6', leading to much higher H2 uptake in the isomer with catenation. Hydrogen sorption measurements at pressures up to 50 bar demonstrate that framework catenation can be favorable for the enhancement of hydrogen adsorption. For example, the excess hydrogen uptake of PCN-6 is 72 mg/g (6.7%) at 77 K/50 bar or 9.3 mg/g (0.92%) at 298 K/50 bar, resp., and that for PCN-6' is 42 mg/g (4.0%) at 77 K/50 bar or 4.0 mg/g (0.40%) at 298 K/50 bar. Importantly, PCN-6 exhibits a total hydrogen uptake of 95 mg/g (8.7%) (corresponding to a total volumetric value of 53.0 g/L, estd. based on crystallog. d.) at 77 K/50 bar and 15 mg/g (1.5%) at 298 K/50 bar. Significantly, the expected usable capacity of PCN-6 is ≤75 mg/g (or 41.9 g/L) at 77 K, if a recharging pressure of 1.5 bar is assumed.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1cXhtlant7jM&md5=b018a4fc4ba711f6ee6bb222fb5fcc94
        (c) Yuan, D.; Zhao, D.; Zhou, H.-C. Inorg. Chem. 2011, 50, 10528– 10530

        Pressure-Responsive Curvature Change of a "Rigid" Geodesic Ligand in a (3,24)-Connected Mesoporous Metal-Organic Framework
        Yuan, Daqiang; Zhao, Dan; Zhou, Hong-Cai
        Inorganic Chemistry (2011), 50 (21), 10528-10530CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
        A (3,24)-connected mesoporous metal-org. framework, PCN-69, of stoichiometry Cu3(H2O)3(btti)·16H2O·20H2O (H6btti = 5,5',5''-(benzene-1,3,5-triyl-tris(biphenyl-4,4'-diyl))triisophthalic acid) was synthesized by linking a hexatopic ligand btti with dicopper paddlewheel clusters. This material has rigid connectivity but a flexible framework, which was attributed to a curvature change of the ligand.

        24d
        Effects of Functionalization, Catenation, and Variation of the Metal Oxide and Organic Linking Units on the Low-Pressure Hydrogen Adsorption Properties of Metal-Organic Frameworks
        Rowsell, Jesse L. C.; Yaghi, Omar M.
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2006), 128 (4), 1304-1315CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        The dihydrogen adsorption isotherms of eight metal-org. frameworks (MOFs), measured at 77 K up to a pressure of 1 atm, were examd. for correlations with their structural features. All materials display approx. Type I isotherms with no hysteresis, and satn. was not reached for any of the materials under these conditions. Among the six iso-reticular MOFs (IRMOFs) studied, the catenated materials exhibit the largest capacities on a molar basis, up to 9.8 H2 per formula unit. The addn. of functional groups (-Br, -NH2, -C2H4-) to the phenylene links of IRMOF-1 (MOF-5), or their replacement with thieno[3,2-b]thiophene moieties in IRMOF-20, altered the adsorption behavior by a minor amt. despite large variations in the pore vols. of the resulting materials. But replacement of the metal oxide units with those contg. coordinatively unsatd. metal sites resulted in greater H2 uptake. The enhanced affinities of these materials, MOF-74 and HKUST-1, were further demonstrated by calcn. of the isosteric heats of adsorption, which were larger across much of the range of coverage examd., compared to those of representative IRMOFs. Probably under low-loading conditions, the H2 adsorption behavior of MOFs can be improved by imparting larger charge gradients on the metal oxide units and adjusting the link metrics to constrict the pore dimensions; however, a large pore vol. is still a prerequisite feature.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD28XitV2msg%253D%253D&md5=76a0797beec956e59ca2ddf029f5a386
        (e) Ma, S.; Simmons, J. M.; Sun, D.; Yuan, D.; Zhou, H.-C. Inorg. Chem. 2009, 48, 5263
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        24e
        Porous Metal-Organic Frameworks Based on an Anthracene Derivative: Syntheses, Structure Analysis, and Hydrogen Sorption Studies
        Ma, Shengqian; Simmons, Jason M.; Sun, Daofeng; Yuan, Daqiang; Zhou, Hong-Cai
        Inorganic Chemistry (2009), 48 (12), 5263-5268CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
        Solvothermal assembly of 5,5'-(9,10-anthracenediyl)di-isophthalate (H4adip) with in situ-generated dicopper and diiron paddlewheel secondary building units (SBUs) afforded two porous metal-org. frameworks (MOFs), designated as PCN-14 and PCN-15, resp. The two MOFs crystallize in different structures, characterized by a difference in the dihedral angles between the anthracene and the Ph rings of the adip ligand. PCN-14 retains permanent porosity under dehydration and contains nanoscopic cages while PCN-15 contains only 1-dimensional hexagonal channels along the (0 0 1) direction which require solvent stabilization. The aromaticity of the anthracene rings of the adip ligand in conjunction with the nanoscopic cages grants PCN-14 high excess H adsorption capacity of 2.70% at 77 K, 760 torr (4.42% at satn.), as well as high H affinity of 8.6 kJ/mol at low H2 coverage. These values are compared to other tetracarboxylate-derived MOFs to better understand the role of the arom. rings in H adsorption.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXkvVyktbw%253D&md5=479d3f4262db3434366eb8d52f2dd241

        25
        Hydrogen adsorption in zeolites A, X, Y and RHO
        Langmi, H. W.; Walton, A.; Al-Mamouri, M. M.; Johnson, S. R.; Book, D.; Speight, J. D.; Edwards, P. P.; Gameson, I.; Anderson, P. A.; Harris, I. R.
        Journal of Alloys and Compounds (2003), 356-357 (), 710-715CODEN: JALCEU; ISSN:0925-8388. (Elsevier Science B.V.)
        We have investigated the use of zeolites as potential hydrogen storage materials. The zeolites A, X, Y and rho, which encompass a range of different pore geometries and compns., were synthesized by hydrothermal methods, and different cation-exchanged forms were prepd. by ion-exchange from aq. metal nitrate solns. The phase compn. and crystallinity of samples were investigated by powder x-ray diffraction. SEM revealed cubic crystals of zeolites both before and after ion-exchange. Hydrogen adsorption capacities were measured using a const. pressure thermogravimetric analyzer; data were obtained over a range of pressures from 0 to 15 bar and isothermally at temps. from -196 to 300°. The results showed that hydrogen uptake in zeolites is strongly dependent upon temp., and also on framework and cation type. Surface area measurements were also carried out on these materials and the results were used to interpret the hydrogen adsorption data.
        >> More from SciFinder ®

        Highly porous and robust scandium-based metal-organic frameworks for hydrogen storage
        Ibarra, Ilich A.; Yang, Sihai; Lin, Xiang; Blake, Alexander J.; Rizkallah, Pierre J.; Nowell, Harriott; Allan, David R.; Champness, Neil R.; Hubberstey, Peter; Schroeder, Martin

        The metal-org. frameworks NOTT-400 and NOTT-401, based on a binuclear [Sc2(μ2-OH)(O2CR)4] building block, were synthesized and characterized. The the desolvated framework NOTT-401a shows a BET surface area of 1514 m2/g with a total H2 uptake of 4.44% at 77 K and 20 bar.

        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        26b
        Hydrogen storage and carbon dioxide capture in an iron-based sodalite-type metal-organic framework (Fe-BTT) discovered via high-throughput methods
        Sumida, Kenji; Horike, Satoshi; Kaye, Steven S.; Herm, Zoey R.; Queen, Wendy L.; Brown, Craig M.; Grandjean, Fernande; Long, Gary J.; Dailly, Anne; Long, Jeffrey R.
        Chemical Science (2010), 1 (2), 184-191CODEN: CSHCCN; ISSN:2041-6520. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        Using high-throughput instrumentation to screen conditions, the reaction between FeCl2 and H3BTT·2HCl (BTT3- = 1,3,5-benzenetristetrazolate) in a mixt. of DMF and DMSO gave Fe3[(Fe4Cl)3(BTT)8]2·22DMF·32DMSO·11H2O. This compd. adopts a porous three-dimensional framework structure consisting of square [Fe4Cl]7+ units linked via triangular BTT3- bridging ligands to give an anionic 3,8-net. Moessbauer spectroscopy carried out on a DMF-solvated version of the material indicated the framework to contain high-spin Fe2+ with a distribution of local environments and confirmed the presence of extra-framework iron cations. Upon soaking the compd. in methanol and heating at 135° for 24 h under dynamic vacuum, most of the solvent is removed to yield Fe3[(Fe4Cl)3(BTT)8(MeOH)4]2 (Fe-BTT), a microporous solid with a BET surface area of 2010 m2/g-1 and open Fe2+ coordination sites. Hydrogen adsorption data collected at 77 K show a steep rise in the isotherm, assocd. with an initial isosteric heat of adsorption of 11.9 kJ mol-1, leading to a total storage capacity of 1.1 wt.% and 8.4 g/L-1 at 100 bar and 298 K. Powder neutron diffraction expts. performed at 4 K under various D2 loadings enabled identification of ten different adsorption sites, with the strongest binding site residing just 2.17(5) Å from the framework Fe2+ cation. Inelastic neutron scattering spectra are consistent with the strong rotational hindering of the H2 mols. at low loadings, and further reveal the catalytic conversion of ortho-H2 to para-H2 by the paramagnetic iron centers. The exposed Fe2+ cation sites within Fe-BTT also lead to the selective adsorption of CO2 over N2, with isotherms collected at 298 K indicating uptake ratios of 30.7 and 10.8 by wt. at 0.1 and 1.0 bar, resp.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3cXoslersrY%253D&md5=f82a784cc9592db0cdc75dc8633cafa7
        (d) Li, Y.; Xie, L.; Liu, Y.; Yang, R.; Li, X. Inorg. Chem. 2008, 47, 10372
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        26d
        Favorable Hydrogen Storage Properties of M(HBTC)(4,4'-bipy)·3DMF (M = Ni and Co)
        Li, Yaoqi; Xie, Lei; Liu, Yang; Yang, Rong; Li, Xingguo
        Inorganic Chemistry (2008), 47 (22), 10372-10377CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
        Two metal-org. frameworks of M(HBTC)(4,4'-bipy)·3DMF (M = Ni and Co; H3BTC = 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid; 4,4'-bipy = 4,4'-bipyridine; DMF = N,N'-DMF) were synthesized by a 1-pot soln. reaction and a solvothermal method, resp. The as-prepd. samples have high sp. surface areas of 1590 m2/g and 887 m2/g. The activation at different temps. for the guest removal prior to gas loading obviously affects the gas sorption process. Ni(HBTC)(4,4'-bipy)·3DMF shows high hydrogen storage capacities of 1.20% at room temp. and 3.42% at 77 K Co(HBTC)(4,4'-bipy)·3DMF shows capacities of 0.96% at 298 K and 2.05% at 77 K. The hydrogen adsorption heats in the 2 compds. decrease slightly as a function of the amt. adsorbed, and it confirms that the H2 mols. are combined with stronger sites preferentially. Research on the kinetics of hydrogen adsorption shows a fast satn. process (80 s) and no obvious capacity loss after 20 cycles.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
