        Klein, N.; Senkovska, I.; Baburin, I. A.; Grünker, R.; Stoeck, U.; Schlichtenmayer, M.; Streppel, B.; Mueller, U.; Leoni, S.; Hirscher, M.; Kaskel, S. Chem.—Eur. J. 2011, 17, 13007
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        27
        Route to a Family of Robust, Non-interpenetrated Metal-Organic Frameworks with pto-like Topology
        Klein, Nicole; Senkovska, Irena; Baburin, Igor A.; Gruenker, Ronny; Stoeck, Ulrich; Schlichtenmayer, Maurice; Streppel, Barbara; Mueller, Uwe; Leoni, Stefano; Hirscher, Michael; Kaskel, Stefan
        Chemistry - A European Journal (2011), 17 (46), 13007-13016, S13007/1-S13007/9CODEN: CEUJED; ISSN:0947-6539. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        A combination of topol. rules and quantum chem. calcns. has facilitated the development of a rational metal-org. framework (MOF) synthetic strategy using the tritopic benzene-1,3,5-tribenzoate (btb) linker and a neutral cross-linker 4,4'-bipyridine (bipy). New compds., [M2(bipy)]3(btb)4 (DUT-23(M), M = Zn, Co, Cu, Ni), [Cu2/Zn2(bisqui)]3(btb)4 (DUT-24, bisqui = di-Et (R,S)-4,4'-biquinoline-3,3'-dicarboxylate), [Cu2(py)1.5(H2O)0.5]3(btb)4 (DUT-33, py = pyridine), and [Cu2(H2O)2]3(btb)4 (DUT-34), with high sp. surface areas and pore vols. (up to 2.03 m3 g-1 for DUT-23(Co)) were synthesized. For DUT-23(Co), excess storage capacities were detd. for methane (268 mg g-1 at 100 bar and 298 K), H (74 mg g-1 at 40 bar and 77 K), and n-butane (99 mg g-1at 293 K). DUT-34 is a non cross-linked version of DUT-23 (noninterpenetrated pendant to MOF-14) that possesses open metal sites and can therefore be used as a catalyst. The accessibility of the pores in DUT-34 to potential substrate mols. was proven by liq. phase adsorption. By exchanging the N,N donor 4,4'-bipyridine with a substituted racemic biquinoline, DUT-24 was obtained. This opens a route to the synthesis of a chiral compd., which could be interesting for enantioselective sepn.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3MXht1Crtr%252FO&md5=ff7acf923bc2463e73b0a3b5a6c28044
      28. 28
        Stoeck, U.; Krause, S.; Bon, V.; Senkovska, I.; Kaskel, S. Chem. Commun. 2012, 48, 10841
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        28
        A highly porous metal-organic framework, constructed from a cuboctahedral super-molecular building block, with exceptionally high methane uptake
        Stoeck, Ulrich; Krause, Simon; Bon, Volodymyr; Senkovska, Irena; Kaskel, Stefan
        Chemical Communications (Cambridge, United Kingdom) (2012), 48 (88), 10841-10843CODEN: CHCOFS; ISSN:1359-7345. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        A highly porous metal-org. framework Cu2(BBCDC) (BBCDC = 9,9'-([1,1'-biphenyl]-4,4'-diyl)bis(9H-carbazole-3,6-dicarboxylate)) (DUT-49) with a sp. surface area of 5476 m2 g-1, a pore vol. of 2.91 cm3 g-1, a H2 excess uptake of 80 mg g-1 (77 K, 50 bar), a CO2 excess uptake of 2.01 g g-1 (298 K, 50 bar) and an exceptionally high excess methane storage capacity of 308 mg g-1 (298 K, 110 bar) was obtained using an extended tetratopic linker.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38XhsVyhs7nF&md5=625754155bbd8f3f7fc7ab99cb3d684e
      29. 29
        Furukawa, H.; Ko, N.; Go, Y. B.; Aratani, N.; Choi, S. B.; Choi, E.; Yazaydin, A. O.; Snurr, R. Q.; O’Keeffe, M.; Kim, J.; Yaghi, O. M. Science 2010, 329, 424
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        29
        Ultrahigh Porosity in Metal-Organic Frameworks
        Furukawa, Hiroyasu; Ko, Nakeun; Go, Yong Bok; Aratani, Naoki; Choi, Sang Beom; Choi, Eunwoo; Yazaydin, A. Oezguer; Snurr, Randall Q.; O'Keeffe, Michael; Kim, Jaheon; Yaghi, Omar M.
        Science (Washington, DC, United States) (2010), 329 (5990), 424-428CODEN: SCIEAS; ISSN:0036-8075. (American Association for the Advancement of Science)
        Cryst. solids with extended non-interpenetrating three-dimensional crystal structures were synthesized that support well-defined pores with internal diams. of up to 48 angstroms. The Zn4O(CO2)6 unit was joined with either one or two kinds of org. link, 4,4',4''-[benzene-1,3,5-triyl-tris(ethyne-2,1-diyl)]tribenzoate (BTE), 4,4',44''-[benzene-1,3,5-triyl-tris(benzene-4,1-diyl)]tribenzoate (BBC), 4,4',44''-benzene-1,3,5-triyl-tribenzoate (BTB)/2,6-naphthalenedicarboxylate (NDC), and BTE/biphenyl-4,4'-dicarboxylate (BPDC), to give four metal-org. frameworks (MOFs), MOF-180, -200, -205, and -210, resp. Members of this series of MOFs show exceptional porosities and gas (hydrogen, methane, and carbon dioxide) uptake capacities. For example, MOF-210 has Brunauer-Emmett-Teller and Langmuir surface areas of 6240 and 10,400 square meters per g, resp., and a total carbon dioxide storage capacity of 2870 mg per g. The vol.-specific internal surface area of MOF-210 (2060 square meters per cubic centimeter) is equiv. to the outer surface of nanoparticles (3-nm cubes) and near the ultimate adsorption limit for solid materials.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3cXptVWgsb8%253D&md5=ce5cd4101a6f96dc0d6c349bc478b3b0
      30. 30
        Ma, S.; Sun, D.; Simmons, J. M.; Collier, C. D.; Yuan, D.; Zhou, H.-C. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2008, 130, 1012
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        30
        Metal-Organic Framework from an Anthracene Derivative Containing Nanoscopic Cages Exhibiting High Methane Uptake
        Ma, Shengqian; Sun, Daofeng; Simmons, Jason M.; Collier, Christopher D.; Yuan, Daqiang; Zhou, Hong-Cai
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2008), 130 (3), 1012-1016CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        A microporous metal-org. framework, PCN-14, based on an anthracene deriv., 5,5'- (9,10-anthracene-diyl)di-isophthalate (H4adip), was synthesized under solvothermal reaction conditions. X-ray single crystal anal. revealed that PCN-14 consists of nanoscopic cages suitable for gas storage. N2-adsorption studies of PCN-14 at 77 K reveal a Langmuir surface area of 2176 m2/g and a pore vol. of 0.87 cm3/g. Methane adsorption studies at 290 K and 35 bar show that PCN-14 exhibits an abs. methane-adsorption capacity of 230 vol./vol., 28% higher than the DOE target (180 vol./vol.) for methane storage.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1cXhtlymug%253D%253D&md5=47684d1faab210ef528aa92e5e5754a3
      31. 31
        Burchell, T.; Rogers, M. SAE Tech. Pap. Ser. 2000, 2000
        Google Scholar
        There is no corresponding record for this reference.
      32. 32
        (a) Arstad, B.; Fjellvag, H.; Kongshaug, K. O.; Swang, O.; Blom, R. Adsorption 2008, 14, 755
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        32a
        Amine functionalised metal organic frameworks (MOFs) as adsorbents for carbon dioxide
        Arstad, Bjornar; Fjellvaag, Helmer; Kongshaug, Kjell Ove; Swang, Ole; Blom, Richard
        Adsorption (2008), 14 (6), 755-762CODEN: ADSOFO; ISSN:0929-5607. (Springer)
        Three different porous metal org. framework (MOF) materials have been prepd. with and without uncoordinated amine functionalities inside the pores. The materials have been characterized and tested as adsorbents for carbon dioxide. At 298 K the materials adsorb significant amt. of carbon dioxide, the amine functionalized adsorbents having the highest CO2 adsorption capacities, the best adsorbing around 14 wt% CO2 at 1.0 atm CO2 pressure. At 25 atm CO2 pressure, up to 60 wt% CO2 can be adsorbed. At high pressures the CO2 uptake is mostly dependent on the available surface area and pore vol. of the material in question. For one of the iso-structural MOF pairs the introduction of amine functionality increases the differential adsorption enthalpy (from isosteric method) from 30 to around 50 kJ/mol at low CO2 pressures, while the adsorption enthalpies reach the same level at increase pressures. The high pressure exptl. results indicate that MOF based solid adsorbents can have a potential for use in pressure swing adsorption of carbon dioxide at elevated pressures.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1cXhtlWht77K&md5=1e9e877324ae6bab0e3eb98eabb5a031
        (b) An, J.; Geib, S. J.; Rosi, N. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2009, 132, 38
        [ACS Full Text ], Google Scholar
        There is no corresponding record for this reference.
        (c) Si, X.; Jiao, C.; Li, F.; Zhang, J.; Wang, S.; Liu, S.; Li, Z.; Sun, L.; Xu, F.; Gabelica, Z.; Schick, C. Energy Environ. Sci. 2011, 4, 4522
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        32c
        High and selective CO2 uptake, H2 storage and methanol sensing on the amine-decorated 12-connected MOF CAU-1
        Si, Xiaoliang; Jiao, Chengli; Li, Fen; Zhang, Jian; Wang, Shuang; Liu, Shuang; Li, Zhibao; Sun, Lixian; Xu, Fen; Gabelica, Zelimir; Schick, Christoph
        Energy & Environmental Science (2011), 4 (11), 4522-4527CODEN: EESNBY; ISSN:1754-5706. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        The amine-decorated microporous metal-org. framework CAU-1 was readily synthesized and activated using a home-made efficient protocol. It exhibited a high heat of adsorption for CO2, high CO2 uptake capacity, and an impressive selectivity for CO2 over N2. At 273 K and up to 1 atm, CO2 uptake capacity can reach ≤7.2 mmol/g-1. Comparatively, the CH4 and N2 uptakes at 273 K and 1 atm were only 1.34 mmol/g-1 and 0.37 mmol/g-1, resp. The CO2/N2 selectivity was 101:1 at 273 K The isosteric heat of adsorption (Qst) for CO2 was ∼48 kJ/mol-1 at the onset of adsorption, and it decreases to ∼28 kJ/mol-1 at higher CO2 pressures. Also, CAU-1 can adsorb 2.0% and 4.0% hydrogen at 77 K under 1 atm and 30 atm, resp. The adsorption characteristics of CAU-1 for methanol studied in situ with a quartz crystal microbalance (QCM), indicated that this particular MOF structure can be used as a highly sensitive sensor for methanol detection such as direct methanol fuel cells.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3MXhsVyrtb3J&md5=d594f95f593bdf96a38ab6e5665cf15f
      33. 33
        (a) Lin, J.-B.; Zhang, J.-P.; Chen, X.-M. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2010, 132, 6654
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        33a
        Nonclassical Active Site for Enhanced Gas Sorption in Porous Coordination Polymer
        Lin, Jian-Bin; Zhang, Jie-Peng; Chen, Xiao-Ming
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2010), 132 (19), 6654-6656CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        Gas sorption expts. and grand canonical Monte Carlo simulations for two isostructural microporous metal azolate frameworks show that even partially exposed uncoordinated nitrogens can effectively increase gas binding affinity and overcome the pore size confinement effect. Polymeric cobalt complexes [Co(dpt24)2] (MAF-25) and [Co(mdpt24)2] (MAF-26) where Hdpt24 = 3-(2-pyridyl)-5-(4-pyridyl)-1,2,4-triazole and 3-(3-methyl-2-pyridyl)-5-(4-pyridyl)-1,2,4-triazole (Hmdpt24) were prep., their crystal structures detd. and their adsorption isotherms with N2, H2 and CO2 studied.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3cXltFChtLs%253D&md5=517f8aae38f8c028c9f23cb4d7ac12f2
        (b) Bloch, E. D.; Britt, D.; Lee, C.; Doonan, C. J.; Uribe-Romo, F. J.; Furukawa, H.; Long, J. R.; Yaghi, O. M. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2010, 132, 14382
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        33b
        Metal Insertion in a Microporous Metal-Organic Framework Lined with 2,2'-Bipyridine
        Bloch, Eric D.; Britt, David; Lee, Chain; Doonan, Christian J.; Uribe-Romo, Fernando J.; Furukawa, Hiroyasu; Long, Jeffrey R.; Yaghi, Omar M.
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2010), 132 (41), 14382-14384CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        Reaction of AlCl3·6H2O with 2,2'-bipyridine-5,5'-dicarboxylic acid (H2bpydc) affords Al(OH)(bpydc) (1, MOF-253), the first metal-org. framework with open 2,2'-bipyridine (bpy) coordination sites. The material displays a BET surface area of 2160 m2/g and readily complexes metals to afford, for example, 1·xPdCl2 (x = 0.08, 0.83) and 1·0.97Cu(BF4)2. EXAFS spectroscopy performed on 1·0.83PdCl2 reveals the expected square planar coordination geometry, matching the structure of the model complex (bpy)PdCl2. Significantly, the selectivity factor for binding CO2 over N2 under typical flue gas conditions increases from 2.8 in 1 to 12 in 1·0.97Cu(BF4)2.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3cXhtFygt7bP&md5=6981a0152668936def128aab676d03cf
        (c) Yazaydin, A. Ö.; Snurr, R. Q.; Park, T.-H.; Koh, K.; Liu, J.; Levan, M. D.; Benin, A. I.; Jakubczak, P.; Lanuza, M.; Galloway, D. B.; Low, J. J.; Wills, R. R. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2009, 131, 18198
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        33c
        Screening of Metal-Organic Frameworks for Carbon Dioxide Capture from Flue Gas Using a Combined Experimental and Modeling Approach
        Yazaydin, A. Ozgur; Snurr, Randall Q.; Park, Tae-Hong; Koh, Kyoungmoo; Liu, Jian; LeVan, M. Douglas; Benin, Annabelle I.; Jakubczak, Paulina; Lanuza, Mary; Galloway, Douglas B.; Low, John J.; Willis, Richard R.
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2009), 131 (51), 18198-18199CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        A diverse collection of 14 metal-org. frameworks (MOF) for flue gas CO2 capture are reported. Synthesis, characterization, and adsorption measurements for about half the MOF are reported; adsorption data were collected from the literature for the remaining MOF. The diversity of the selected materials will help improve the understanding fo MOF CO2 capture. Also, these data were used to validate a general strategy for mol. modeling of CO2 and other small mols. in MOF. This strategy is fully predicting with no parameter-fitting. This approach can be used to rapidly screen addnl. MOF, saving large amts. of exptl. time and costs. Grand canonical Monte Carlo simulations were performed for a model which included electrostatic and Lennard-Jones interactions among atoms in the system. The framework and individual CO2 mols. are considered to be rigid. Interactions among CO2 mols. were modeled with the TraAPPE force field (J.J. Potoff and J.I. Siepmann, 2001); Lennard-Jones parameters for MOF atoms were taken from DREIDING (S.L. Mayo, et al., 1990) and UFF (A.K. Rappe, et al., 1992) force fields. Partial charges on MOF atoms were derived from d. functional theory calcns.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXhsFShsr7L&md5=ee067ec4cee9d1095897b19d957671db
      34. 34
        (a) Farha, O. K.; Yazaydin, A. O.; Eryazici, I.; Malliakas, C. D.; Hauser, B. G.; Kanatzidis, M. G.; Nguyen, S. T.; Snurr, R. Q.; Hupp, J. T. Nat. Chem. 2010, 2, 944
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        34a
        De novo synthesis of a metal-organic framework material featuring ultrahigh surface area and gas storage capacities
        Farha, Omar K.; Oezguer Yazaydin, A.; Eryazici, Ibrahim; Malliakas, Christos D.; Hauser, Brad G.; Kanatzidis, Mercouri G.; Nguyen, Son-Binh T.; Snurr, Randall Q.; Hupp, Joseph T.
        Nature Chemistry (2010), 2 (11), 944-948CODEN: NCAHBB; ISSN:1755-4330. (Nature Publishing Group)
        Metal-org. frameworks, a class of porous hybrid materials built from metal ions and org. bridges, have recently shown great promise for a wide variety of applications. The large choice of building blocks means that the structures and pore characteristics of the metal-org. frameworks can be tuned relatively easily. However, despite much research, it remains challenging to prep. frameworks specifically tailored for particular applications. Here, the authors used computational modeling to design and predictively characterize a metal-org. framework (NU-100) with a particularly high surface area. Subsequent exptl. synthesis yielded a material [Cu3(L)(H2O)3]n (NU-100/PCN-610, H6L = hexatopic carboxylate I), matching the calcd. structure, with a high BET surface area (6,143 m2 g-1). Also, sorption measurements revealed that the material had high storage capacities for H2 (164 mg g-1) and CO2 (2,315 mg g-1) - gases of high importance in the contexts of clean energy and climate alteration, resp. - in excellent agreement with predictions from modeling.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3cXhtlWksbjN&md5=706f3b3b6b4cb7d03950103b11ba023e
        (b) Zhao, D.; Yuan, D.; Yakovenko, A.; Zhou, H.-C. Chem. Commun. 2010, 46, 4196
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        34b
        A NbO-type metal-organic framework derived from a polyyne-coupled di-isophthalate linker formed in situ
        Zhao, Dan; Yuan, Daqiang; Yakovenko, Andrey; Zhou, Hong-Cai
        Chemical Communications (Cambridge, United Kingdom) (2010), 46 (23), 4196-4198CODEN: CHCOFS; ISSN:1359-7345. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        A NbO-type metal-org. framework, PCN-46, was constructed based on a polyyne-coupled di-isophthalate linker formed in situ. Its lasting porosity was confirmed by N2 adsorption isotherm, and its H2, CH4 and CO2 adsorption capacity was examd. at 77 K and 298 K over a wide pressure range (0-110 bar).
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3cXmvVGgurc%253D&md5=2f22d7679438be96776fe91953c64fa5
      35. 35
        Millward, A. R.; Yaghi, O. M. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2005, 127, 17998
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        35
        Metal-Organic Frameworks with Exceptionally High Capacity for Storage of Carbon Dioxide at Room Temperature
        Millward, Andrew R.; Yaghi, Omar M.
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2005), 127 (51), 17998-17999CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        Metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) show high CO2 storage capacity at room temp. Gravimetric CO2 isotherms for MOF-2, MOF-505, Cu3(BTC)2, MOF-74, IRMOF-11, IRMOF-3, IRMOF-6, IRMOF-1 and MOF-177 are reported up to 42 bar. Type I isotherms are found in all cases except for MOFs based on Zn4O(O2C)6 clusters, which reveal a sigmoidal isotherm. The various pressures of the isotherm steps correlate with increasing pore size, which indicates potential for gas sepns. The amine functionality of the IRMOF-3 pore shows evidence of relatively increased affinity for CO2. Capacities qual. scale with surface area and range from 3.2 mmol/g for MOF-2 to 33.5 mmol/g (320 cm3(STP)/cm3, 147 wt %) for MOF-177, the highest CO2 capacity of any porous material reported.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2MXht1GktLnJ&md5=ad433b990b72836a16c8647c09ec85f2
